facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 25, 1961 of the Kerala High Court in S.A. No. 852 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 25, 1961 of the Kerala High Court in S.A. No. 852 of 1957.

facts.text: In 1921, the plaintiff executed in favour of the defendant an otti kuzhikanam deed in respect of the suit property.

anchor.surface_text: In 1921, the plaintiff executed in favour of the defendant an otti kuzhikanam deed in respect of the suit property.

facts.text: By the 1921 deed, the plaintiff sold to the defendant the building standing on the property for 350 fanams.

anchor.surface_text: By this deed, the plaintiff sold to the defendant the building standing on the property for 350 fanams and also transferred to him for 350 fanams the right to possess and enjoy the property for 12 years in kuzhikanam right with liberty to plant companyonut trees thereon,

facts.text: The 1921 deed transferred to the defendant the right to possess and enjoy the property for 12 years in kuzhikanam right with liberty to plant coconut trees thereon.

anchor.surface_text: By this deed, the plaintiff sold to the defendant the building standing on the property for 350 fanams and also transferred to him for 350 fanams the right to possess and enjoy the property for 12 years in kuzhikanam right with liberty to plant companyonut trees thereon, expressly reserving for the plaintiff the right to enjoy the fruit bearing trees then standing on the property

facts.text: The 1921 deed expressly reserved for the plaintiff the right to enjoy the fruit bearing trees then standing on the property.

anchor.surface_text: expressly reserving for the plaintiff the right to enjoy the fruit bearing trees then standing on the property The deed provided that after the expiry of 12 years the defendant would on demand demolish and take away the building and surrender possession of the land on receipt of 350 fanams and the agreed companypensation for the companyonut trees planted by him.

facts.text: The 1921 deed provided that after the expiry of 12 years the defendant would on demand demolish and take away the building and surrender possession of the land on receipt of 350 fanams and the agreed compensation for the coconut trees planted by him.

anchor.surface_text: The deed provided that after the expiry of 12 years the defendant would on demand demolish and take away the building and surrender possession of the land on receipt of 350 fanams and the agreed companypensation for the companyonut trees planted by him.

facts.text: The plaintiff instituted a suit for redemption of the property.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff instituted a suit for redemption of the property.

facts.text: During the pendency of the litigation, the plaintiff and the defendant died, and their legal representatives were substituted.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the litigation, the plaintiff and the defendant died, and their legal representatives were substituted in their place.

facts.text: On May 31, 1951, the Principal District Munsif Quilon decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: On May 31, 1951, the Principal District Munsif Quilon decreed the suit.

facts.text: On appeal, the District Court of Quilon affirmed the decree of the Munsif.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the District Court of Quilon affirmed this decree.

facts.text: The present appellant, one of the legal representatives of the original defendant, filed a second appeal in the High Court of Kerala.

anchor.surface_text: The present appellant, who is one of the legal representatives of the original defendant, filed a second appeal in the High Court of Kerala.

facts.text: During the pendency of the second appeal in Kerala High Court, the Kerala Agrarian Relations Act, 1960 (Act IV of 1961) came into force.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this appeal, the Kerala Agrarian Relations Act, 1960  Act IV of 1961  came into force.

facts.text: Before the High Court, the appellant claimed fixity of tenure and protection from eviction as a kuzhikanamdar or holder of a kudiyiruppu under Act IV of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court, the appellant claimed fixity of tenure and protection from eviction on the ground that he was a kuzhikanamdar or alternatively, the holder of a kudiyiruppu, and, therefore, a tenant within the meaning of s. 2 50   i  e  read with s. 2 22  and s. 2 50  i  j  read with s. 2 21  of Act IV of 1961.

facts.text: The Kerala High Court negatived the appellant's contentions and dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived this companytention, and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: The appellant appeals to this Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant number appeals to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: During the pendency of this Supreme Court appeal, Act IV of 1961 was repealed and the Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1963 (Act 1 of 1964) came into force.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this appeal, Act IV of 1961 was repealed and the Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1963  Act 1 of 1964  came into force.

facts.text: The appellant claims fixity of tenure and protection from eviction as a kuzhikanamdar under s.2(57)(d) read with s.2(28) of Act 1 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant number claims fixity of tenure and protection from eviction on the ground that he is a, kuzhi- kanamdar within the meaning of s. 2 57  d  read with s. 2 28 ,

facts.text: Alternatively, the appellant claims to be the holder of a kudiyiruppu under s.2(57)(h) read with s.2(26) of Act 1 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: or alternatively, the holder of a kudiyiruppu within the meaning of s. 2 57  h  read with s. 2 26  of Act 1 of 1964.

facts.text: In the High Court, the appellant claimed protection as a kudikidappukaran, but this contention was negatived and is no longer pressed.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, the appellant also claimed protection from eviction on the ground that he was a kudikidappukaran, but this companytention was negatived by the High Court and is numberlonger pressed.

facts.text: The deed of 1921 was styled otti kuzhikanam deed.

anchor.surface_text: The deed of 1921 was styled otti kuzhikanam deed.

facts.text: In Malabar, the word otti designates a possessory mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: In Malabar, the word otti in the companytext of the deed designates a possessory mortgage.

facts.text: The deed of 1921 expressly reserved for the grantor the right to enjoy the fruit-bearing trees then standing on the land and did not transfer those trees to the grantee.

anchor.surface_text: Now the deed of 1921, while effecting a transfer of land for the purpose of planting companyonut trees thereon, expressly reserved for the grantor the right to enjoy the fruit-bearing trees then standing on the land and did number transfer those trees to the ,grantee.

facts.text: There is no material on the record to show that the building on the land is a residential building.

anchor.surface_text: I here is numbermaterial on the record to show that the building on the land is a residential building.

facts.text: The contention that the appellant is the holder of kudiyiruppu is rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that the appellant is the holder of kudiyi- ruppu is rejected.

facts.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 25, 1961 of the Kerala High Court in S.A. No. 852 of 1957.
The appellant number appeals to this Court by special leave.
During the pendency of this appeal, the Kerala Agrarian Relations Act, 1960  Act IV of 1961  came into force.

issues.text: Whether the appellant is a kuzhikanamdar within the meaning of s.2(57)(d) read with s.2(28) of the Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1964, entitling him to fixity of tenure and protection from eviction under s.13?

anchor.surface_text: The appellant number claims fixity of tenure and protection from eviction on the ground that he is a, kuzhi- kanamdar within the meaning of s. 2 57  d  read with s. 2 28 ,

anchor.surface_text: or alternatively, the holder of a kudiyiruppu within the meaning of s. 2 57  h  read with s. 2 26  of Act 1 of 1964.

issues.text: Whether the definition of kuzhikanam in s.2(28) requires transfer of the fruit-bearing trees (if any) standing on the land at the time of transfer for their enjoyment by the transferee, or whether transfer of land merely for planting new trees suffices?

anchor.surface_text: The deed of 1921 was styled otti kuzhikanam deed. In Malabar, the word otti in the companytext of the deed designates a possessory mortgage.

arguments.claim: Words 'with the fruit-bearing trees, if any, standing thereon at the time of the transfer, for the enjoyment of those trees' are not essential parts of definition of kuzhikanam in s.2(28); transfer of land for planting fruit-bearing trees thereon suffices even without transfer or enjoyment of existing trees.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, it was argued that the words with the fruit-bearing trees, if any, standing thereon at the time of the transfer, for the enjoyment of those trees are number essential parts of the definition of kuzhikanam in s. 2 28 , and that we should hold that a transfer of land for the purpose of planting fruit-bearing trees thereon is kuzhikanam,

arguments.court_reasoning: Transfer of land without fruit-bearing trees standing on it and without right to enjoy those trees is not kuzhikanam as defined in s.2(28); 'if any' requires transfer of such trees if present for transferee's enjoyment.

arguments.claim: Definition of kuzhikanam in s.2(28) of Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1964 is both inclusive and exhaustive, controlling over customary meaning unless context requires otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: This definition of kuzhikanam is both inclusive and exhaustive. Unless the companytext requires otherwise, the expression kuzhikanam in the Act can have only the meaning given in S. 2 28 . There is numberhing in the companytext of S. 2 57  and s. 13, which requires a different meaning for this expression.

arguments.claim: Kuzhikanam under s.2(28) means transfer of garden/other lands with fruit-bearing trees (if any) standing thereon at transfer time, for enjoyment of those trees and for planting more; excludes usufructuary mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: Kuzhikanam as defined in s. 2 28  means a transfer  1  of garden lands or of other lands or of both,  2  with the fruit-bearing trees, if any, standing thereon at the time of the transfer,  3  for the enjoyment of those trees and  4  for the purpose of planting such fruitbearing trees thereon.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ge as defined in the Transfer of Property Act, 1882. This definition of kuzhikanam is both inclusive and exhaustive. Unless the companytext requires o

arguments.claim: Appellant contends he is tenant under s.2(57)(d) and s.2(57)(h) inclusive definitions, not under main part of s.2(57).

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 57  defines tenant. By sections 2 57  d  and  h , a tenant includes a kuzhikanamdar and the holder of a kudiyiruppu. The appellant does number companytend that he is a tenant as defined in the main part of s. 2 57 . He, however, companytends that he is a tenant as defined in s. 2 57  d  and s. 2 57  h .

arguments.court_reasoning: Concedes not under main part; claims under inclusions rejected on facts and definition.

arguments.court_reasoning: Negatived by High Court; no longer pressed before Supreme Court.

holdings.text: This definition of kuzhikanam is both inclusive and exhaustive. Unless the context requires otherwise, the expression kuzhikanam in the Act can have only the meaning given in S. 2 28 . There is nothing in the context of S. 2 57  and s. 13, which requires a different meaning for this expression.

anchor.surface_text: This definition of kuzhikanam is both inclusive and exhaustive. Unless the companytext requires otherwise, the expression kuzhikanam in the Act can have only the meaning given in S. 2 28 . There is numberhing in the companytext of S. 2 57  and s. 13, which requires a different meaning for this expression.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definitions in land reform acts are controlling and exhaustive unless context demands otherwise; no such context in s.2(57) or s.13.

holdings.text: Kuzhikanam as defined in s. 2 28  means a transfer 1 of garden lands or of other lands or of both, 2 with the fruit-bearing trees, if any, standing thereon at the time of the transfer, 3 for the enjoyment of those trees and 4 for the purpose of planting such fruitbearing trees thereon.

anchor.surface_text: Kuzhikanam as defined in s. 2 28  means a transfer  1  of garden lands or of other lands or of both,  2  with the fruit-bearing trees, if any, standing thereon at the time of the transfer,  3  for the enjoyment of those trees and  4  for the purpose of planting such fruitbearing trees thereon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual parsing of s.2(28) breaks down elements required for kuzhikanam, emphasizing transfer includes existing trees if any for transferee's enjoyment.

holdings.text: A transfer of land without the fruit-bearing trees then standing on it and not carrying with it the right to enjoy those trees is not a kuzhikanam as defined in s. 2 28 . The force of the words 'if any' requires that if there are fruit-bearing trees, they must be transferred for enjoyment by the transferee.

anchor.surface_text: We think that a transfer of land without the fruit-bearing trees then standing on it and Dot carrying with it the right to enjoy those trees is number a L S5SCI-11 a  kuzhikanam as defined in s. 2 28 . The force of the words if any in the definition is that if there are any fruit- bearing trees on the land at the time of the transfer, the trees also must be transferred for their enjoyment by the transferee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects appellant's textual argument by emphasizing 'if any' clause mandates inclusion of existing trees in transfer for transferee enjoyment; 1921 deed fails this.

holdings.text: The contention that the deed of 1921 granted kuzhikanam rights as defined in s. 2 28  of Act 1 of 1964 is rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The contention that the deed of 1921 granted kuzhikanam rights as defined in s. 2 28  of Act 1 of 1964 is rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.2(28) interpretation to facts of 1921 deed which reserved existing trees to grantor, denying transferee enjoyment right.

holdings.text: There is no material on the record to show that the building on the land is a residential building. Moreover, it does not appear that the land is necessary for the convenient enjoyment of the building. The contention that the appellant is the holder of kudiyiruppu is rejected.

anchor.surface_text: I here is numbermaterial on the record to show that the building on the land is a residential building. Moreover, it does number appear that the land is necessary for the companyvenient enjoyment of the building. The companytention that the appellant is the holder of kudiyiruppu is rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(26) requires residential building and necessary lands; no record evidence of either.

holdings.text: Had there been no special definition of the expression kuzhikanam in Act 1 of 1964, we would have been inclined to hold that the grantee under the deed of 1921 was a kuzhikanamdar.

anchor.surface_text: Had there been numberspecial definition of the expression kuzhikanam in Act 1 of 1964, we would have been inclined to hold that the grantee under the deed of 1921 was a kuzhikanamdar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical observation based on customary Malabar understanding of kuzhikanam as possessory right for 12 years to plant trees.
